awd_titl_txt: GP-IN: Chesapeake-Student Recruitment, Early Advisement, and Mentoring (C-StREAM) to Diversify Leadership in the Geosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Through the IUSE:GEOPAths project, the Chesapeake Research Consortium, Inc. (CRC) and its partners aim to evolve and strengthen a leadership pathway that attracts and retains a diverse community of both undergraduate mentees and mentors so that the necessary diversity of perspectives is applied to the understanding of complex human-impacted ecosystems. The project is intended to strengthen and further develop, improve, and evaluate the CRC’s recently created and unique program, Chesapeake-Student Recruitment, Early Advisement, and Mentoring (C-StREAM). In its current form, C-StREAM develops and trains a diverse population of future leaders in environmental research, restoration, and protection by engaging them over multiple years in mentored engagement experiences. While this initial pipeline construction has been successful, there are structural elements that can be strengthened so that it can be filled to capacity. The PIs intend to do this by individually tailoring the arc of the entire student engagement experience, over multiple years, and by deeply integrating the students within the full intellectual ecosystem of the Chesapeake Bay restoration effort, which is a partnership of students, senior researchers across a variety of institutional settings, managers, and policy-makers working to develop and apply scientific understanding of the Chesapeake Bay regional ecosystem.

In order to strengthen the existing pathway model (a multi-year experience associated with a large ecosystem restoration effort), the PIs specifically will focus on building the confidence and competency of participants (Fellows) toward continued study in their field of interest and an eventual career of contribution to environment-related careers by: a) providing access to a summer internship program that allows them to explore both sides of actionable science (i.e., science and its application in management and policy) by offering opportunities from multiple on-going, impactful internship programs at two different federal agencies and multiple (currently seven) CRC member or partnering institutions; b) employing a common language of leadership competencies that can be developed by the student through the program, so that specific experiences can be woven together in a cohesive arc and tailored to the individual needs of the student; c) building a strong sense of belonging by providing the Fellows of any given annual cohort (of roughly a dozen students) multiple and substantive opportunities to create community, enhance communication skills, and have shared professional development experiences; d) creating a community of practice composed of well-respected and professionally well-connected summer mentors who are not only highly skilled in areas of direct intellectual interest to the student, but also trained to be culturally aware, articulate in leadership competencies, and responsive to the student’s needs so that the program experience can be leveraged to its fullest potential; e) incentivizing each Fellow to continue to pursue interests that they’ve developed (from the summer experience or otherwise) during the academic year and in collaboration with home institution advisors and mentors, to bridge the summer experiences to create a thoughtful and individually-tailored arc of engagement; and f) connecting Fellows (via access during common activities and encouragement by mentors) with more than one professional mentor, including individuals both within and outside their home institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the Chesapeake-Student Recruitment, Early Advisement, and Mentoring (C-StREAM) project is to evolve and strengthen a leadership pathway that attracts and retains a diverse community of both undergraduate mentees and mentors (targeting populations who have been historically excluded from the environmental field and are therefore currently underrepresented in environmental research and management professions) so that the necessary diversity of perspectives is applied to the protection and restoration of complex human-impacted ecosystems.  There are three unique aspects of the program that distinguish it from other internship programs.  First, it operates in the context of the multi-dimensional actionable science network of the Chesapeake Bay restoration effort, including researchers across a variety of institutional settings (academic, agency, and Non-governmental Organizations (NGOs)), municipal officials, citizens, managers, and policy-makers working to develop and apply scientific understanding toward an established, large, visible, and complex environmental challenge.  This context offers three important learning opportunities:  firstly, discovery has a high standard of potential applicability towards a real-world challenge; secondly, the restoration effort is well-organized and mature in its governance; and thirdly, it provides a wide window into potential career paths across a variety of institutional settings.  The second unique aspect of the program is its use of a recognized set of competencies to guide the experiences, assessment, and mentoring of the students during the arc of their involvement. Our aim is to develop each Fellow in a way that prepares them to assume positions of leadership in the environmental field, which requires the identification of specific competencies and methods to assess their level of development. The concept of building a portfolio of competencies encourages students to return for additional experiences in second or third summers of participation, and in programs that are guided by mentors to benefit the areas of competency where the student and mentors see the greatest continuing need.  The competency-based approach utilized in this project is proving effective at several scales:  providing an important evaluation tool for the interns to see personal growth in a quantitative way; allowing interns to pro-actively structure their educational experience past the summer's activities; and as a framework for mentors to assist in the growth of their interns.  The competency-based approach is a transferable pedagogical tool.  Finally, we support both students and mentors with extensive mentoring, development, and community-building opportunities during the summer and academic year, creating a strong community of practice around best approaches.

 

The C-StREAM program has delivered value at three scales:  to the over 45 individual students that have participated in the 4 years of the NSF-supported program, to the ability of institutions and organizations (including academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, regulatory agencies, and other partners) to effectively mentor students from underrepresented groups, and ultimately to the restoration effort.  The past and current projects illuminate the high level of scientific and technical contribution that these students make, and the diverse range of disciplines that they cover and that are all necessary components of the current environmental challenge.  Their host organizations represent a wide swath of the Bay’s stakeholders, adding impact at a societal scale.  Finally, members of initial cohorts are proving the power of the program by populating leadership positions.  In so doing, the project delivers broader impacts in the areas of inclusion by focusing on students from populations typically underrepresented in environmental fields, improving STEM education and educator development through its mentor training and assessment, developing a more diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce through the preparation of a leadership pathway, increasing public scientific literacy and public engagement with STEM via a large portfolio of communication platforms and media, building partnerships between a wide variety of partner organizations that host interns, and ultimately improving the well-being of individuals in society through both current contributions of projects and the future contributions of leadership, expertise, and inspiration to others as they gain leadership positions.
